awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Efficient Modeling of Incompressible Fluid Dynamics at Moderate Reynolds Numbers by Deconvolution LES Filters - Analysis and Applications to Hemodynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Computational fluid dynamics has emerged as a powerful tool to study the physiopathology of the cardiovascular system and for patient-specific Surgical Planning (SP) for cardiovascular diseases. Recently, clinical trials - the standard procedure for understanding diseases and assessing the impact of therapies and devices in the clinical practice - have been supported by a massive use  of numerical simulations to improve the knowledge extracted from measured data, leading to Computer Aided Clinical Trials (CACT). For a large variety of pathologies involving the aorta - the major artery of the circulation - this requires to work with turbulent flows. While Direct Numerical Simulation in this context can be appropriate for a proof of concept, for the large number of patients involved in CACT and SP we need different numerical tools to provide the appropriate trade-off between accuracy and reliability needed by clinical applications and computational efficiency needed by tight deadlines. As CACT and SP are new emerging concepts in cardiovascular mathematics, an appropriate numerical modeling of turbulent physiological flows for clinical applications is now an unmet need that we intend to solve in this proposal.

A possible way to limit the computational costs associated with Direct Numerical Simulations without sacrificing accuracy is to solve the flow average and model properly the effects of the small scales (not directly solved) at the medium and large scales (solved). We intend to investigate carefully new cutting-edge methods for disturbed flows based on Large Eddy Simulation (LES) Deconvolution filtering techniques with the ultimate goal of enabling practical use of numerical tools to improve knowledge extraction and clinical practice through CACT and SP. The main objective of this research is the development and the analysis of a robust and accurate LES based approach requiring no or minimal user's set-up for realistic incompressible flow problems with application to computational hemodynamics. We articulate the project in the following points: (a) Sensitivity analysis of key parameters involved in the method to understand their impact on the solution, leading to an automated parameter set-up through physical and numerical arguments. (b) Development and analysis of high-order in time methods, particularly for the computation of the pressure, with consequent improvement of the mass conservation properties. (c) Analysis of the impact of our LES approach on non-Dirichlet boundary conditions and the possible backflow stabilizing effects.  We plan to test the method on both academic and real bioengineering problems. Finally, we plan to deliver a finite element open source library incorporating the findings of our research, available for CACT and SP.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this research was the development and the analysis of a robust and accurate Large Eddy Simulation (LES) based approach requiring no or minimal user's set-up for realistic incompressible flow problems with application to computational hemodynamics. The high computational cost of the Direct Numerical Simulation of the Navier-Stokes equations prevents the use of scientific computing in routine clinical practice. By solving the flow average and model properly the effects of the small scales (not directly solved) at the medium and large scales, our LES approach substantially reduces the computational time, especially when combined with a Reduced Order Modeling (ROM) strategy. 

The major contributions of this projects are: 

  1.  We developed and analyzed a filtering stabilization technique that provides numerical results in good agreement with experimental data. This technique is a reliable tool for patient-specific analysis of the hemodynamics in the aorta and it automatically provides backflow stabilization.
  2.  High-performance computing software was developed and validated. The suite of scripts and codes created for our LES approach combined with a Finite Element method are available for download (www.lifev.org).
  3. We applied our LES approach to simulate the Coanda effect (eccentric regurgitant jets) in an anatomically correct heart chamber developed at the Houston Methodist Hospital. Results from this research have made impact in the area of echocardiographic assessment of mitral valve regurgitation. In particular, they led to a better understanding of the formation and structure of mitral regurgitant jets, which will impact the accuracy in clinical assessment of severity of mitral valve regurgitation.
  4. We have developed a hybrid projection/data-driven ROM for our nonlinear filtering stabilization. We showed that not only the results are accurate when compared to the full-order method (our LES approach combined with a Finite Volume method), but the reduction in the computational times is significant. The code generated for this project is available in open source software ITHACA-FV (https://mathlab.sissa.it/ithaca-fv).

 The results of the project have been disseminated in 33 peer-reviewed papers (preprints available at the grant website https://www.math.uh.edu/~quaini/styled/styled-6/styled-7/) and a large number of invited seminars, colloquia, lectures, and presentations at national and international conferences. Research by two undergraduate students has been supported by this grant and three supported graduate students graduated in 2019. Several other students at the graduate and post-doc level contributed to topics related to this project with no support. 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2021
Modified by: Annalisa Quaini
